info.headline: Extreme Fire Danger issued September 08 at 3:40AM MDT by NWS Sioux Falls
info.description: .DISCUSSION... Issued at 427 AM CDT Thu Sep 8 2022 Expecting two rounds of near-critical and critical fire weather conditions today for portions of the region west of I-29, with the first round occurring out ahead of a cold front and the second on the backside of the cold front. By the mid-morning hours critically low relative humidity values will begin moving into portions of the Missouri River Valley, with breezy southwesterly winds gusting up to 35 mph. Through the afternoon hours, a cold front will begin moving into areas starting west of the James River Valley, which will act to weaken surface winds until the front has finished passing through. Behind the front, expect a rapid shift towards west and then northerly winds. This will be the second round of concern as dry air will also be present behind the cold front, with winds gusting up to 35 mph. Have upgraded portions of the watch to a full Red Flag Warning, while also adding Bon Homme and Yankton counties, due to the hot, dry, and breezy conditions expected. Did keep a couple counties in the watch while also adding Hanson and Hutchinson counties for the potential of Red Flag conditions, with the main concern being how far eastward the dry air is able to get. While there will be a couple periods where wind speeds will reach criteria, just not sure if red flag conditions will be able to sustain themselves long enough to warrant the upgrade at this time. With fuels west of I-29 certainly cured enough, the next shift will need to monitor new model data and observations to see if a short-term upgrade is warranted. Debris burning is the number one cause of wildfires...so please be careful with any use of fire. ...EXTREME FIRE DANGER... The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the extreme category this afternoon. Extreme weather conditions and very low moisture content of grasses, and other dry organic material on the ground, indicate that critical burning conditions exist. All fires have the potential to become large and spread quickly, becoming erratic with extreme behavioral characteristics. No outdoor burning should take place. OUTLOOK FOR FRIDAY AFTERNOON...The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the moderate category. The grassland fire danger product reflects fire danger for native grasses. It is not intended for cured agricultural crops, nor will it reflect conditions in road ditches which have been mowed.
